user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BSP_Initialize:
```c
void OS_BSP_Initialize(void)
{
    FILE *              fp;
    char                buffer[32];
    pthread_mutexattr_t mutex_attr;
    int                 status;

    /*
     * If not running as root, check /proc/sys/fs/mqueue/msg_max
     *
     * This special file represents the max depth of a POSIX message queue for an unprivileged user.
     *
     * In order to facilitate running in simulation mode without any need for root access --
     * this will allow the OSAL to successfully create message queues by truncating anything larger than this size.
     *
     * No need to check _LINUX_OS_ here; if the file fails to open, i.e. if not on Linux and the file does not exist,
     * then leave well enough alone and don't do anything.
     */
    if (geteuid() != 0)
    {
        fp = fopen("/proc/sys/fs/mqueue/msg_max", "r");
        if (fp)
        {
            if (fgets(buffer, sizeof(buffer), fp) != NULL)
            {
                OS_BSP_Global.MaxQueueDepth = OSAL_BLOCKCOUNT_C(strtoul(buffer, NULL, 10));
                BSP_DEBUG("Maximum user msg queue depth = %u\n", (unsigned int)OS_BSP_Global.MaxQueueDepth);
            }
            fclose(fp);
        }
    }

    /* Initialize the low level access mutex (w/priority inheritance) */
    status = pthread_mutexattr_init(&mutex_attr);
    if (status < 0)
    {
        BSP_DEBUG("pthread_mutexattr_init: %s\n", strerror(status));
    }
    status = pthread_mutexattr_setprotocol(&mutex_attr, PTHREAD_PRIO_INHERIT);
    if (status < 0)
    {
        BSP_DEBUG("pthread_mutexattr_setprotocol: %s\n", strerror(status));
    }
    status = pthread_mutex_init(&OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessMutex, &mutex_attr);
    if (status < 0)
    {
        BSP_DEBUG("pthread_mutex_init: %s\n", strerror(status));
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_BSP_Initialize:
extern OS_BSP_GlobalData_t OS_BSP_Global
...
OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobalData_t OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal
...
#define OSAL_BLOCKCOUNT_C(X) ((osal_blockcount_t)(X))
...
#define BSP_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No function parameters are present in OS_BSP_Initialize (it has a void parameter list), so there are no function parameters that can be modified in this function. The code only uses local variables (fp, buffer, mutex_attr, status) and global objects (OS_BSP_Global, OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal). Calls that take pointer arguments (e.g. pthread_mutexattr_init(&mutex_attr), pthread_mutexattr_setprotocol(&mutex_attr,...), pthread_mutex_init(&OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessMutex,...), fgets(buffer,..., fp), strtoul(buffer,...)) either pass the address of local objects (allowed: the pointed-to object may be modified) or pass NULL as an endptr (no parameter is modified). Assignments such as fp = fopen(...) and OS_BSP_Global.MaxQueueDepth = ... modify a local variable and a global, respectively — neither are function parameters. The BSP_DEBUG macro expands to nothing per the provided definition, so it cannot hide any modification of a function parameter. Therefore there are no code fragments in this function that require investigation for Rule 17.8.
